Description:
The Virgin is supported by cherubim and stylized clouds and supports the Christ Child in her arms. She carries a rosary in her right hand while Christ holds an orb in one hand, signifying sovereignty over the world, raising the other in blessing. The painted decoration, chiefly of the rich clothing (imitating brocade) of the Virgin and Christ Child, is original and would contriubte to impression of royal status of the mother and child.
 This approach to surface decoration, entirely chracteristic of ivory devotional statuettes carved in the Philippines in the 1600s, is thought by specialists in the field to reflect the presence in the Philippines of larger-scale devotional sculpture by Martínez Montañés (1568-1649), a sculptor in Seville, Spain's primary port for trade with its world-wide network of colonies.  In contrast, the Virgin's face with its heavy-leaded eyes, reflects more closely a sensibility associated with Chinese carving. For the importance of Chinese artisans in the Philippines, see 71.490. 
For a devotional statuette of the Virgin and Child carved in the Philippines that appears to be more closely reflective of Chinese traditions of carving, see 71.358.

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Second Floor: Chamber of Wonders

Provenance: Henry Walters, Baltimore [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Our Lady of the Rosary
